questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided back pain. For several weeks, the patient has had worsening, poorly localized right back pain. The pain radiates to the thigh and knee. He does not have a recent history of trauma. Past medical history includes poorly controlled HIV, chronic hepatitis C, and intravenous heroin use. The patient last injected heroin two days ago. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), blood pressure is 107/67 mmHg, and pulse is 106/min. Pain is elicited with passive extension of the right leg. Physical examination of the back is without focal tenderness, step-offs, or deformities. The patient has an antalgic gait. Neurovascular examination of the bilateral lower extremities is non-contributory, and the patient can void freely. If untreated, this patient is at risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of immunosuppression presents with poorly localized right back pain and a positive iliopsoas sign. The physical examination is negative for findings of cauda equina syndrome, epidural abscess, or other sources of infection. Together, these clinical findings are concerning for a psoas abscess, which can lead to femoral nerve damage if untreated.

A psoas abscess is a collection of pus in the iliopsoas compartment; it may result from an infection's contiguous, hematogenous, or postoperative spread. While rare, it more commonly presents in patients with underlying immunosuppression, diabetes, or intravenous drug use.

Clinically, this disease presents with fever and subacute, poorly localized back or flank pain radiating to the knee, in addition to gait disturbance or neuropathy if the femoral nerve is implicated. If the abscess becomes large enough, it may be palpable in the inguinal region and mistaken for an inguinal hernia, lymphadenopathy, or saphenous vein varix.

The femoral nerve courses anteriorly along with the iliopsoas and thus may become damaged as the disease progresses. Damage to this nerve may ultimately result in femoral neuropathy, manifesting with quadriceps weakness, decreased patellar reflexes, as well as sensory loss along the medial thigh and leg. Diagnosis is best achieved via a contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis. Management includes empiric antibiotics and source control via percutaneous or surgical intervention.  

Option Analysis

✅ Femoral neuropathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rectus sheath hematoma:
Incorrect: Injury to the inferior epigastric artery may occur with incisions or surgical procedures performed below the arcuate line (e.g. cesarean section). Failure to identify and ligate these arteries may result in rectus sheath hematoma formation. However, this patient does not have a history of recent surgeries or trauma.  
❌ Diverticulum perforation:
Incorrect: Diverticulum perforation can occur in the setting of untreated, complex diverticulitis. Diverticulitis more commonly presents in the left lower quadrant with alternating diarrhea, constipation, and fever. Diverticula typically develop in elderly individuals and thus would be unlikely in this patient, given his age.  
❌ Pyogenic liver abscess  :
Incorrect: Pyogenic liver abscesses may result from bacterial seeding or a complication from biliary tract pathology. This patient’s clinical presentation reflects a psoas abscess given his age and risk factors.  
❌ Bilateral lower extremity paraplegia  :
Incorrect: Bilateral lower extremity paraplegia is a devastating consequence of acute spinal cord compression or cauda equina syndrome. In contrast, this patient has a history of intravenous drug use, immunosuppression, and positive iliopsoas sign. Neurovascular examination of the lower extremities is unremarkable. In combination, these findings are more suggestive of a psoas abscess.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate low back pain. The patient was using the rowing machine at the gym when he felt a “pop” in his back followed by pain. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient has tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine and diminished sensation over the anterior aspect of the left leg. The patient has 4/5 strength with hip flexion on the left compared to 5/5 strength on the right. Which of the following physical examination maneuvers is most likely to demonstrate a positive finding given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of low back pain and findings of L2-L4 radiculopathy, including diminished sensation over the anterior aspect of the leg and decreased strength with hip flexion. Given these findings, the exam maneuver most likely to be positive is the straight leg raise, which often reproduces symptoms of sciatic nerve root compression.    

The evaluation of low back pain involves a detailed examination, beginning with inspection and palpation for tenderness, step-offs, and deformities. When radiculopathy is suspected, additional examination maneuvers include checking the lower extremities for reflexes, strength, and sensation. Special examination techniques include the straight leg raise, which is performed with the patient lying down on their back, and the examiner lifts the patient's leg while the knee is straight. Reproduction of pain with radiation down the leg indicates a positive test.



Specific sensory or motor findings can also indicate the anatomic location of radiculopathy. For example, L2-L4 radiculopathy often presents with pain and diminished sensation radiating down the anterior aspect of the thigh and occasionally into the medial part of the lower leg, with associated weakness of hip flexion, knee extension, and hip adduction. L5 radiculopathy presents with pain and loss of sensation down the lateral aspect of the leg into the foot, with associated diminished foot dorsiflexion, toe extension, foot inversion, and foot eversion. Lastly, S1 radiculopathy presents with pain and diminished sensation that radiates down the posterior aspect of the leg, with associated weakness of plantar flexion, leg extension, and knee flexion, along with a diminished ankle jerk reflex.  

Option Analysis

✅ Straight leg raise test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stork test :
Incorrect: The stork test, also known as the Gillet test, assesses for sacroiliac joint movement between the innominate and sacrum through the clinician's palpation of the posterior superior iliac spine during knee flexion. A positive test is an indication of sacroiliac joint hypomobility. 
❌ Thessaly test:
Incorrect: The Thessaly test, like the McMurray test, is used to detect meniscal injuries of the knee, not lumbosacral radiculopathy.  
❌ Ober test:
Incorrect: The Ober test detects tension in the iliotibial band, not lumbosacral radiculopathy.   
❌ FABER test:
Incorrect: The FABER test evaluates hip pathology by flexing, abducting, and externally rotating the hip. It is not helpful for the evaluation of lumbosacral radiculopathy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office due to an acute onset of back pain. Two hours ago, he felt a sharp, middle-back pain while lifting a heavy box. The patient describes the pain as “shooting” and burning, 7/10 in severity, and radiating from the back to the right foot. He does not have any bowel or bladder symptoms. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, knee jerk and Achilles reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Straight leg raise is positive on the right side. Motor strength for dorsiflexion is 5/5 on the left compared to 3/5 on the right lower extremity. Which of the following nerve roots is most likely affected by this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute onset of low back pain after heavy lifting. The presence of pain radiating from the back to the foot and weakness in dorsiflexion is consistent with lumbosacral radiculopathy of L5 spinal nerve root.  

Radiculopathy refers to any disease process that affects the function of one or more lumbosacral nerve roots as they exit the spinal cord. Lumbosacral radiculopathy is often caused by nerve root compression due to disc herniation or spondylosis (degenerative changes). The compressed nerve carries both sensory and motor fibers. The specific sensory distribution of a single nerve root is termed dermatome, while the muscles served by a single spinal nerve root are termed myotome. Due to these features, a neurological exam that includes sensory, strength, and reflex evaluation can assist in the localization of the injury.  

It is important to note, however, that if an injury occurs to the peripheral nerves which are formed by integration of multiple nerve roots, the distribution will be according to the peripheral nerve innervation rather than myotomes and dermatomes. “Sciatica” is a non-specific term often applied to various conditions of low back pain with/without radiation to the leg regardless of the cause. The use of this term is often confusing and should be avoided when describing radiculopathy.  



Option Analysis

❌ L1:
Incorrect: Lumbar disc herniation at the L1 level is rare, and therefore L1 radiculopathy is unlikely. Injury to L1 will result in pain, paresthesia, and sensory loss along L1 dermatome in the inguinal region. Rarely, minor hip flexion weakness may be seen.
❌ L4:
Incorrect: Compression of the L4 nerve will likely present as knee extension weakness (quadriceps), hip flexion weakness (iliopsoas), and loss of the knee jerk reflex. In addition, sensory impairment along the L4 dermatome from the anterior thigh down to the medial aspect of the lower leg would be expected.
✅ L5:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ S1:
Incorrect: Compression of the S1 nerve root will result in weakness in plantar flexion (gastrocnemius), hip extension (gluteus maximus), and knee flexion (biceps femoris). Sensation will likely be reduced on the posterior leg and the lateral edge of the foot. Achilles reflex loss is typical.
❌ S2:
Incorrect: Compression of S2 will result in hip extension weakness (gluteus maximus), knee flexion weakness (hamstrings), and ankle plantarflexion weakness (gastrocnemius). Sensory impairment along the S2 dermatome from the posterior thigh down to the medial plantar arch would be expected.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician to evaluate low back pain and left leg weakness. The patient has had worsening low back pain over the past three weeks, with pain radiating into her groin. The patient has also had difficulty maintaining poses due to weakness and pain during her yoga classes.  The patient recently had an upper respiratory infection six weeks ago that resolved. The patient also reports falling on her back several weeks ago while skiing in Colorado. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes oral contraceptive pills daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness to palpation over the lumbar vertebrae and reproduction of pain when raising the left leg to 45 degrees. Reflex testing demonstrates 1+ reflexes of the patellar tendon and 2+ reflexes of the Achilles tendon in the left leg. The patient has 4/5 strength with hip flexion and knee extension in the left leg compared to 5/5 strength with these maneuvers in the right leg. Which of the following best describes the underlying etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Posterolateral herniation of the nucleus pulposus
Post-infectious autoimmune demyelination of peripheral nerves
Collapse and loss of height of the vertebral bodies
Inflammation of the lateral corticospinal tract
Neural foraminal stenosis due to degenerative arthritis

questions.solution:
The most common cause of radiculopathy in young, otherwise healthy patients is intervertebral disc herniation of the nucleus pulposus. This otherwise healthy patient presents for evaluation of low back pain and unilateral leg weakness. The physical examination findings are consistent with L2-L4 radiculopathy, given the associated weakness of hip flexion, knee extension, and a diminished knee jerk reflex.    

The vertebral bodies are cushioned against one another by a ring of cartilage called intervertebral discs. The rounded region in its center is called the nucleus pulposus, and the nucleus pulposus is surrounded by a fibrous ring called the annulus fibrosus. Typically, the annulus fibrosus is thinner posteriorly and doesn’t receive support from the posterior or the anterior longitudinal ligaments.    

Movements that result in forward flexion of the spine can compress the anterior portion of the disc, pushing the nucleus pulposus posterolaterally. Most commonly, this occurs at the L4-L5 or L5-S1 levels. Over time, or with extreme flexion of the spine, the annulus fibrosus can degrade or break, resulting in posterolateral protrusion of the disk, which can compress motor or sensory nerve roots, producing radicular symptoms.  



Option Analysis

✅ Posterolateral herniation of the nucleus pulposus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Post-infectious autoimmune demyelination of peripheral nerves:
Incorrect: Guillain Barre syndrome more commonly presents with bilateral, ascending symmetric leg weakness. The unilateral clinical findings in this patient make this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Collapse and loss of height of the vertebral bodies:
Incorrect: Collapse and loss of height of the vertebral bodies is usually a result of compression fractures uncommon in otherwise healthy individuals. Compression fractures more commonly occur in the elderly with underlying osteopenia or osteoporosis.  
❌ Inflammation of the lateral corticospinal tract   :
Incorrect: Transverse myelitis reflects an autoimmune or inflammatory process directly affecting the spinal cord. Since this pathology is directly related to the central nervous system, symptoms of hyperreflexia or increased tone are more likely to be present.  
❌ Neural foraminal stenosis due to degenerative arthritis:
Incorrect: Neural foraminal stenosis due to degenerative arthritis is a common culprit of lumbosacral radiculopathy in the elderly, not in otherwise young, healthy patients.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of worsening low back pain with walking. The patient's symptoms have been ongoing for over 8 months. The pain is worsened with standing  upright and walking  and relieved with sitting. There is no relief when he continues standing upright but stops walking. He sometimes experiences pain and tingling into the buttocks and legs. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and fifteen-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination does not reveal any bony tenderness or defects of the lumbar spine. Neurologic assessment demonstrates 5/5 strength of the lower extremities bilaterally and a normal sensory examination. Straight leg raise is negative bilaterally. A digital rectal exam demonstrates an enlarged prostate without bogginess or asymmetry and adequate rectal tone. A radiograph of the lumbar spine shows only osteophytes. Further history is most likely to elicit which of the following regarding this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This older patient presents for evaluation of low back pain and buttocks and leg pain worsened with walking and standing and relieved with sitting but not when he stops walking but continues to stand. These findings are consistent with spinal stenosis. A characteristic feature of spinal stenosis is pain relief with bending forward at the waist, as it helps offload pressure and widens the spinal canal. Which is in contrast to leg pain seen in vascular claudication which is worse with walking and relieved when the patient stops walking even when they remain upright.  

Spinal stenosis refers to narrowing of the vertebral foramen in one or more vertebrae, typically in the lumbar region. Most commonly, this is an age-related condition due to osteoarthritis and progressive disk degeneration that results in facet joint arthropathy, osteophyte formation, and hypertrophy of the ligamentum flavum. These processes ultimately result in the narrowing and impingement of the central spinal canal.  

Clinically, spinal stenosis results in “neurogenic claudication”, which refers to worsening pain with walking or standing upright, and relief with sitting where there is forward flexion at the waist. lying flat, or bending forward. In more severe cases, impingement on the central canal can compress spinal nerves, resulting in numbness, weakness, or tingling in the extremities. In most cases, the physical examination is non-contributory unless associated neurologic deficits are present.

Option Analysis

✅ Pain relief with bending forward:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Twenty-pound weight loss:
Incorrect: The diagnosis of primary or metastatic bone malignancy, especially prostate cancer in men, should always be considered when evaluating older men with low back pain. However, this patient’s prostate exam demonstrates only an enlarged prostate. Spinal stenosis which this patient has signs and symptoms of is commonly caused by arthritic changes in the spine and not metastases.  
❌ Loss of lower extremity hair:
Incorrect: Loss of lower extremity hair is commonly found in patients with vascular claudication from peripheral artery disease. Leg pain in this condition is worsened with walking and improved when the patient stops walking which is not seen in this patient.  
❌ History of osteoporosis:
Incorrect: Compression fractures result from underlying osteoporosis. This patient’s imaging does not show evidence of a vertebral body compression fracture.  
❌ Urinary retention:
Incorrect: Cauda equina syndrome is a neurologic emergency that arises from compression of the spinal cord at the level of the cauda equina. Associated symptoms include urinary retention, loss of bowel or bladder control, poor rectal tone, and weakness of the lower extremities. In rare cases spinal stenosis can lead to cauda equina syndrome.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of chronic back pain. The patient has been experiencing worsening back pain over the past five months which is what brought them into the clinic. The patient has not experienced any sensory changes or bowel or bladder loss of control. She has no difficulty walking. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, obesity, and osteoporosis. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for anterior pelvic tilt, and increased curvature of the lumbar spine without abnormalities in the rest of the spine. The patient has full range of motion of the lumbar spine without pain. A radiograph is obtained and shown below. Which of the following best describes this patient’s findings?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of worsening chronic back pain and is found to have an anterior pelvic tilt and excessive curvature of the lumbar spine on physical examination. Furthermore, radiography demonstrates excessive lumbar lordosis or an increase in inward curvature of the lumbar vertebrae.  

The spine's normal curvature typically follows four normal curvatures, which can be seen on a lateral view radiograph. These include thoracic and sacral kyphosis. Kyphosis is an increased front to back curve of the spine giving a convex curve in the spine (i.e., convexity towards the back of the spine). in those areas. There is also a normal cervical and lumbar lordosis giving a gently concave curve in those areas (i.e, concavity towards the back of the spine). Two common spinal abnormalities include excessive thoracic or thoracolumbar kyphosis and excessive lumbar lordosis.  

Excessive kyphosis typically occurs in the thoracic region and leads to a hunchback appearance. This process can be postural or due to vertebral compression fractures from osteoporosis, osteoarthritis, or spondylolisthesis. Additional etiologies include genetic disorders such as Scheuermann kyphosis, osteogenesis imperfecta, or metabolic or congenital disabilities like spina bifida.  

Excessive lumbar lordosis results in the presence of an anterior pelvic tilt or swayback posture on physical examination. It is most often due to poor posture, obesity, weak hamstrings, tight hip flexors, or osteoporosis. Like excessive kyphosis, excessive lumbar lordosis is also associated with several genetic disorders, including Ehlers-Danlos syndrome and achondroplasia. It can lead to lumbar pain and if untreated, excessive lumbar lordosis may result in slippage of intervertebral discs, radiculopathy, and spondylolisthesis.

Option Analysis

✅ Excessive lumbar lordosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Excessive thoracolumbar kyphosis:
Incorrect: Thoracolumbar kyphosis refers to excessive thoracic/lumbar convexity seen in the sagittal plane.. This finding is  not present in this patient’s radiograph or examination. Patients with thoracic or thoracolumbar kyphosis have exaggerated forward rounding of the upper back on physical exam  
❌ Scoliosis:
Incorrect: Scoliosis refers to an abnormal curvature of the spine in the coronal plane, resulting in lateral displacement of the spine. It is difficult to evaluate for scoliosis on a lateral spinal radiograph, however this patient does not have abnormal lateral curvature of the spine on physical examination.  
❌ Spondylolisthesis:
Incorrect: Spondylosis refers to an anatomic defect or fracture of the pars interarticularis. Spondylosis may progress to spondylolisthesis, characterized by anterior displacement of the vertebral body. This patient’s radiograph does not demonstrate spondylolisthesis.  
❌ Vertebral body compression fracture:
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of osteoporosis, the radiograph does not demonstrate evidence of a compression fracture. It shows excessive curvature of the lumbar spine.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after falling at home. The patient typically gets around using a walker. However, she was not using it today, tripped, and fell from standing height. The patient is experiencing low back pain. She was otherwise in good health and had no weight loss, fevers, or increased fatigue. She has never smoked cigarettes. Vitals are within normal. Body mass index is 30 kg/m2. The patient is lying supine on a gurney and in moderate distress on initial evaluation. On physical examination, tenderness is elicited with palpation of the lumbar spine. An initial radiograph of the lumbar spine is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the greatest risk factor predisposing the patient to her current condition?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This older patient presents for evaluation of low back pain after a fall from a standing height. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness over the lumbar spine, and radiography demonstrates an L3 lumbar compression fracture. The most significant risk factor for developing vertebral compression fractures in this patient is underlying osteoporosis.  

Osteoporosis is a disease primarily of older patients, most often seen in post-menopausal women. It results from an imbalance between bone resorption and bone formation resulting from osteoclastic bone resorption not compensated by osteoblastic bone formation. Risk factors for osteoporosis include estrogen deficiency, chronic steroid use, smoking, alcohol use, malnutrition, low BMI, and certain medications such as anticonvulsants.  

Patients with osteoporosis can have vertebral body compression fractures secondary to falls, but they can also experience them with everyday activities like twisting, coughing, and reaching. With osteoporosis, the horizontal trabeculae of the vertebral body becomes weak and the remaining vertical trabeculae are less able to resist compression. With minor falls, such as falls from standing height, compression fractures can occur, resulting in the appearance of short and wedge-shaped vertebrae on radiography.  

Option Analysis

✅ Advanced osteoporosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: This patient sustained a compression fracture of the L3 vertebra body. Advanced osteoporosis is a significant risk factor for developing compression fractures. Having a low body mass index, not obesity, increases the risk of osteoporosis in women.  
❌ Falling from standing height:
Incorrect: Falling from a significant height increases the risk of vertebral body compression fractures even in patients without underlying osteoporosis. In older patients falls from standing height and sitting positions can lead to vertebral compression fractures especially in patient with underlying osteoporosis.  
❌ Nonsmoking history:
Incorrect: Smoking is a risk factor for developing osteoporosis. This patient’s nonsmoking history would decrease her risk of developing osteoporosis and subsequent compression fractures.  
❌ Spinal metastases:
Incorrect: Osteoporosis is the most common cause of compression fractures, but spinal metastases can also be a cause. This patient's radiograph does not show bony metastases, and the patient has no systemic signs or symptoms of malignancy.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for low back pain. The patient has had right-sided, persistent low back pain that is worse with the movement since falling off a six-foot ladder last week. The patient states, “I could not get out of my chair, the pain was so bad”. Past medical history is notable for nephrolithiasis, obesity, and hypertension. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and consumes alcohol occasionally. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness to palpation over the right flank and right lumbar paraspinal area with limited range of motion of the back secondary to pain. He has no spinal tenderness. No hip or groin pain is elicited with flexion, internal, and external rotations of the hips bilaterally. Straight leg raise is negative bilaterally. A plain film of the spine is shown below along with initial laboratory findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with right-sided low back pain, for which the differential diagnosis is broad. In the absence of associated systemic symptoms, the most common etiology of low back pain is a lumbosacral strain of the paraspinal muscles.  

Strains, sprains, and spasms represent the majority of musculoskeletal back injuries, which largely occur in the setting of recent trauma, injury, or heavy lifting. Risk factors for these injuries include occupational hazards, such as heavy lifting and frequent back movement. Additional risk factors include advanced age, obesity, lack of exercise and stretching, and smoking.  

Back strains refer to injury of the muscles or ligaments of the back. Back sprains refer to injury of the ligamentous tissue or their attachment sites to the bone. Finally, spasms refer to involuntary muscle contractions in response to inflammation.  

Management of these injuries is largely supportive, including applying ice or heat packs and taking over-the-counter analgesia or antiinflammatory agents.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lumbosacral strain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nephrolithiasis:
Incorrect: Nephrolithiasis should be in the differential for this patient, given the flank pain and history of recurrent kidney stones. However, his urinalysis shows no evidence of hematuria making nephrolithiasis less likely. Instead, this patient’s symptoms can be better explained by lumbosacral muscle strain.  
❌ Lumbar radiculopathy:
Incorrect: Lumbar radiculopathy most commonly results from the bulging of intervertebral discs. Symptoms often include low back pain and associated pain radiating down the lower extremities. Straight leg raise is typically positive with this condition. This patient is not experiencing radicular pain.  
❌ Osteoarthritis of the hip:
Incorrect: Osteoarthritis of the hip more commonly occurs in older patients. Pain is typically experienced in the groin area with hip motion. This patient does not have any reproducible pain when the hip is moved, and he does not complain of groin pain.  
❌ Vertebral body compression fracture:
Incorrect: While this patient sustained a recent fall, the lumbar film does not show evidence of fracture making vertebral body compression fracture unlikely in this patient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic due to back pain for the past 2 months. The patient reports dull, low back pain that is 3/10 in severity and managed with pain medications. He has not had any similar pain in the past or any recent trauma. He has tried ibuprofen, which provided partial relief. The pain often awakes the patient at night, but he is able to go back to sleep. He did not notice any specific aggravating or relieving factors. Medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, obesity, and osteoarthritis. Medication includes metformin and ibuprofen as needed. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is within normal limits, except mild pain upon palpation at the lumbar area. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient’s back pain?
questions.solution:
This patient has new onset non-mechanical back pain (not related to movement) that is present at night and does not respond to pain medication, which raises concerns for an underlying malignancy (e.g. prostate cancer with metastases to the back).  

Approximately 85% of adults will experience low back pain at some time in their lives. Most cases are self-limited. The vast majority of cases are defined as nonspecific low back pain (85%), meaning that no specific underlying condition has been identified. Less than 10% of individuals who present to a primary care provider for low back pain will have mild but specific etiologies (e.g. disc herniation) and less than 1% will have serious etiologies (e.g., metastatic cancer, cauda equina syndrome). Due to these statistics, imaging for low back pain without associated symptoms is not recommended since it does not change outcomes and increases the use of invasive procedures. That being said, the clinician must recognize the patients who present with red flag symptoms and pursue appropriate investigations.



Option Analysis

❌ Inflammatory:
Incorrect: Inflammatory back pain includes spondyloarthropathies (e.g. ankylosing spondylitis) and is characterized by morning stiffness, improvement with activity, and pain at night. However, this patient did not report any alleviating factors, and patients with ankylosing spondylitis are typically between the age of 30-50 years.
❌ Degenerative:
Incorrect: Spondylosis (degenerative changes of the spine) is a common cause of back pain in individuals over 60 years. Pain due to degenerative changes is often mechanical, meaning it worsens with activity and improves with rest. The pain usually responds to medications. This patient has a new onset of back pain which is not mechanical and does not respond to medications.
✅ Neoplastic:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Infectious:
Incorrect: Vertebral osteomyelitis may occur due to hematogenous spread of an infection, trauma, or contiguous spread from an adjacent infection. Patients often present with insidious onset of back pain and possibly fever over weeks to months. CRP and ESR are usually elevated, whereas WBC count may be elevated or normal. Although further testing should be performed to exclude osteomyelitis, this patient lacks risk factors, such as IV drug use or trauma, making this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Nonorganic:
Incorrect: Nonorganic findings are those that do not have a direct anatomical cause. Psychological conditions, such as depression, somatization disorder, and anxiety, can contribute to the severity of low back pain or cause nonorganic back pain. This patient has no history of psychological conditions, and a nonorganic etiology would not explain the night pain he is experiencing.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the clinic due to back pain. Upon entering the clinic, the patient is observed to be limping and appears in pain. He discloses back pain for the past few months that has been progressively worsening. Two days ago, he felt severe pain while lifting a box at home. The patient now describes the pain as dull, 7/10 in severity, which worsens with movement and radiates to the left thigh. He has noticed numbness in the perianal region while using the toilet. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, focal tenderness is noticed over the lumbar and paraspinal area. There is a loss of sensation around the perianal area but a normal anal sphincter tone. Knee jerk reflex is normal but the ankle reflex is absent on the left. Strength is 5/5 on the right and 4/5 in the left gluteus maximus and hamstring muscles. Which of the following features will prompt the need for emergent imaging?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute lumbar radiculopathy and loss of sensation in the perianal area (saddle anesthesia) which raises concerns for cauda equina syndrome, a medical emergency.    

The spinal cord travels through the spinal canal to the 2nd lumbar vertebra, where it ends in a cone, called the conus medullaris. Because the spinal cord is shorter than the spinal canal, nerves of the lumbar, sacral, and coccygeal regions have to travel down the spinal canal to reach their corresponding openings, forming a nerve bundle below the spinal cord called the cauda equina. These nerves carry motor innervation for the genitals, internal and external anal sphincter, detrusor muscle, leg muscles, and sensory fibers of the legs and pelvis.    

Cauda equina syndrome is caused by compression, trauma, or damage to multiple nerves of the cauda equina. Large lumbar disc herniation is the most common cause of cauda equina syndrome. Other causes include spinal stenosis, spondylolisthesis, cancer, abscess, ankylosing spondylitis, and trauma. Symptoms of cauda equina syndrome include loss of bowel and bladder control, saddle anesthesia, sexual dysfunction, motor weakness, loss of knee and ankle reflexes, radiating pain, and even paraplegia.   

Patients with back pain presenting with a progressive or severe motor deficit not localized to a single nerve root, urinary retention or fecal incontinence, saddle anesthesia, bilateral signs and symptoms (not localized to a single nerve root), or suspected malignancy or abscess should undergo emergency MRI or CT with contrast (if MRI is contraindicated). If cauda equina syndrome is confirmed, an emergency decompression should be performed within 24 hours (12 hours if possible).  



Option Analysis

❌ The patient’s back pain intensity:
Incorrect: Back pain intensity is subjective and is not an indication for imaging and further evaluation in acute settings. Instead, different levels of pain might help in directing the pharmacological choice.
❌ The patient’s back pain characteristics:
Incorrect: Pain characteristic is subjective information that can help the physician to differentiate between different etiologies (e.g. nociceptive pain vs. neuropathic pain). However, it is not an indication for imaging and further evaluation.
❌ The patient’s motor weakness:
Incorrect: Severe motor weakness or significant motor deficits that cannot be localized to a single nerve root are indications for imaging. However, this patient’s weakness is moderate, and the pain has not worsened since onset two days ago.
✅ The patient’s loss of sensation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ The patient’s absent reflex:
Incorrect: Absent reflexes are a common finding in acute lumbar radiculopathy and are not an indication for imaging. Babinski and clonus are upper motor neuron signs that should prompt further evaluation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the clinic due to progressive back pain for the past 2 months. He describes night pain and some morning stiffness that improves with a morning stretching routine. The pain is 3/10 in severity, dull, and located in the lower back. Recently, he started experiencing pain in the right wrist and left ankle, which he attributed to a strenuous basketball game that he took part in. He is working as a computer engineer and has difficulty concentrating due to pain. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is limited spine mobility during flexion and some redness and warmth around the right wrist and left knee. The rest of the physical examination is within normal limits. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which of the following?

choices.text: IgM antibody against IgG Fc region

questions.solution:
This young patient is presenting with an insidious onset, progressive back pain, morning stiffness which improves with movement, night pain, and asymmetric oligoarthritis. He most likely has ankylosing spondylitis.  

Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of seronegative spondyloarthritis (negative rheumatoid factor), a group of autoimmune conditions characterized by arthritis with a strong association with HLA-B27 (MHC class I serotype). These include psoriatic arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, reactive arthritis, juvenile spondyloarthropathies, and ankylosing spondylitis. HLA-B27 testing is part of the diagnostic evaluation.  

These conditions share common features including inflammation of the axial joints (especially sacroiliac joint), asymmetric oligoarthritis, dactylitis (sausage digits), uveitis, and enthesitis (inflammation at the sites where tendons or ligaments insert into the bone). According to the Assessment of SpondyloArthritis international Society (ASAS) criteria, "inflammatory back pain" should be suspected if 4/5 of the following criteria are present:  

  • Age of onset <40 years  
  • Insidious onset  
  • Improvement with exercise  
  • No relief with rest  
  • Pain at night that improves upon arising  

Option Analysis

❌ HLA DR2 positive genotype:
Incorrect: HLA DR2 positive genotype is associated with multiple conditions including multiple sclerosis, hay fever, systemic lupus erythematosus, and Goodpasture syndrome. It is not associated with spondyloarthropathies.
❌ IgM antibody against IgG Fc region:
Incorrect: IgM antibody against IgG Fc region (rheumatoid factor) can be found in many patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), an autoimmune disorder characterized mainly by joint inflammation and destruction. RA leads to symmetric joint involvement rather than oligoarthritis.
✅ HLA B27 positive genotype:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Antibodies against DNA topoisomerase-I:
Incorrect: Anti-Scl-70 antibody (anti-DNA topoisomerase-I antibody) and anti-RNA polymerase III are associated with diffuse scleroderma, an autoimmune condition characterized by skin sclerosis, noninflammatory vasculopathy, and visceral involvement.
❌ Antibodies against signal recognition particle:
Incorrect: Antibodies against signal recognition particle (anti-SRP) can be found in patients with polymyositis and dermatomyositis. Both are autoimmune conditions characterized by muscle inflammation, pain, and weakness. Dermatomyositis can also cause skin involvement.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male comes to the physician due to back pain. 2 months ago, he started having back pains which he attributed to the strenuous interval training he attended at that time. The patient discloses morning pain and stiffness which improves after his morning exercise routine. The pain often awakes him at night, but he is able to go back to sleep. On physical examination, pain is reproduced with palpation of the sacroiliac joint and spinal flexion is limited. Estimated erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 75 mm/hr. This patient’s condition is also associated with which of the following?

choices.text: Sclerosis of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts
Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion

questions.solution:
This young patient is presenting with an insidious onset of progressive back pain, morning stiffness which improves with movement, and night pain. He most likely has ankylosing spondylitis (AS).  

Ankylosing means stiffening, spondylo- refers to the vertebra, and -itis refers to inflammation. AS is a type of seronegative spondyloarthritis (negative rheumatoid factor), a group of autoimmune conditions characterized by arthritis and a strong association with HLA-B27 (MHC class I serotype). These include psoriatic arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, reactive arthritis, juvenile spondyloarthropathy, and ankylosing spondylitis. HLA-B27 testing is part of the diagnostic evaluation.  

These conditions share common features including inflammation of the axial joints (especially the sacroiliac joint), asymmetric oligoarthritis, dactylitis (sausage digits), uveitis, and enthesitis (inflammation at the sites where tendons or ligaments insert into the bone). AS is also associated with increased risk of cardiovascular diseases, including aortic root disease, acute coronary syndrome, stroke, venous thromboembolism, and conduction abnormalities. Patients with AS often have elevated ESR and CRP, as well as characteristic changes in the sacroiliac joint on a plain radiograph (erosions, ankylosis, changes in joint width, and sclerosis). Management includes NSAIDs, disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, and other agents.  

According to the Assessment of SpondyloArthritis international Society (ASAS) criteria, "inflammatory back pain" should be suspected if 4/5 of the following criteria are present:  

  • Age of onset <40 years  
  • Insidious onset  
  • Improvement with exercise  
  • No relief with rest  
  • Pain at night that improves upon arising  


Option Analysis

❌ Recurrent conjunctival inflammation:
Incorrect: Ankylosing spondylitis and other seronegative spondyloarthropathies are associated with uveitis, not conjunctivitis. Although both conditions are associated with eye redness, uveitis is an intraocular inflammation while conjunctivitis is superficial (the tissue that lines the inner surface of the eyelid).
❌ Nail pitting:
Incorrect: Nail pitting occurs due to a focal area of abnormal keratinization. It is associated with conditions such as psoriasis, alopecia areata, and eczema.
❌ Sclerosis of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts:
Incorrect: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is associated with ulcerative colitis (UC). UC is also associated with spondyloarthropathy. However, this patient's presentation is more consistent with ankylosing spondylitis, another type of seronegative spondyloarthritis.
❌ Scoliosis:
Incorrect: Scoliosis refers to the sideways curvature of the spine that occurs most commonly during the growth spurt before puberty. Spinal deformities may be seen in patients with advanced ankylosing spondylitis and include flexion deformity of the neck, thoracic hyperkyphosis, loss of lumbar lordosis, and deformities of the hips. However, it is not associated with scoliosis.
✅ Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents to his primary care provider to evaluate lower back pain. The symptoms began two days ago after he attempted to lift a heavy bookshelf. The patient has not experienced incontinence or muscular weakness in the lower extremities. He currently rates the pain as 5 out of 10 in severity.  His past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which he takes amlodipine and lisinopril. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 135/73 mmHg, and pulse is 62/min. On physical examination, there is mild tenderness over the lumbar paraspinal muscles. Pain is exacerbated with flexion and extension of the lumbar spine. Strength and sensation are intact in the bilateral lower extremities. The remainder of the physical exam is noncontributory. Laboratory testing is shown below. The patient is prescribed a short course of cyclobenzaprine. Which of the following side effects is associated with this medication?
 
Laboratory Value
Results (U.S. conventional units)
Results (SI units)
Hemoglobin
15.1 g/dL
9.38 mmol/L
Leukocyte Count
7,500/mm3
7.5*109/L
Platelet count
270,000/mm3
270*109/L
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
13 mm/hr
13 mm/hr
Creatinine kinase
48 U/L
48 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient presents with musculoskeletal low back pain that has persisted despite applying heat packs and ibuprofen use. As a result, he was started on cyclobenzaprine, which can cause xerostomia as a side effect.

Cyclobenzaprine is a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. Its exact mechanism of action is not fully understood, but studies have demonstrated that the medication antagonizes 5-HT2 receptors within the spinal cord. A similar medication is methocarbamol (its mechanism of action also remains unclear).

Both cyclobenzaprine and methocarbamol can treat musculoskeletal pain (e.g., low back pain, neck pain). In addition, cyclobenzaprine can be used off-label to treat fibromyalgia.

These medications can cause decreased skeletal muscle tone, sedation, drowsiness, confusion, and visual hallucinations. Furthermore, cyclobenzaprine can cause anticholinergic side effects, such as xerostomia, mydriasis, hyperthermia, and constipation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Truncal obesity:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids can be used to treat inflammatory myopathies such as dermatomyositis and polymyositis. These medications can result in the redistribution of adipose tissue from the extremities to the abdomen and subsequent truncal obesity. This patient has a normal ESR and creatinine kinase, making an inflammatory myopathy unlikely.  
❌ Diarrhea:
Incorrect: This patient was prescribed cyclobenzaprine, a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. Cyclobenzaprine also has anticholinergic properties. As a result, the medication can cause constipation, not diarrhea.  
❌ Miosis:
Incorrect: Opioids are a class of pain medications that can cause miosis. These medications bind to mu, kappa, and gamma opioid receptors. In contrast, this patient was started on cyclobenzaprine, a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. Cyclobenzaprine has anticholinergic properties and can cause mydriasis, not miosis.  
✅ Xerostomia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Myoclonus:
Incorrect: This patient was started on cyclobenzaprine to treat low back pain. Serotonin syndrome may develop in patients taking cyclobenzaprine and another pro-serotonergic medication. In contrast, serotonin syndrome would be highly unlikely in patients on cyclobenzaprine monotherapy.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of decreased hearing in the left ear. The symptoms started 2 months ago and have progressively worsened. Her parents state she has difficulty hearing voices and sounds coming from her left. Past medical history is notable for a femoral fracture, which she sustained after falling from standing-height. There is no history of similar symptoms in her family members. The patient’s older sister was recently diagnosed with multiple sclerosis at the age of 20. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg, and pulse is 87/min. The patient is below the 5th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination is notable for hepatosplenomegaly and sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear. Genetic testing reveals a homozygous mutation in the carbonic anhydrase type II gene (CA2). Which of the additional findings will most likely be present on laboratory testing?
questions.solution:
This patient has osteopetrosis, which is characterized by impaired bone resorption. Symptoms vary depending on the disease’s severity and which genes are affected. There are two main types of disease that can occur: infantile malignant osteopetrosis and autosomal-dominant osteopetrosis type II.  

Infantile malignant osteopetrosis (autosomal recessive) presents with severe symptoms that manifest in infancy. A commonly implicated gene is the carbonic anhydrase type II gene (CA2). Homozygous mutation in this gene can result in impaired functioning of osteoclasts, resulting in persistent bone growth. Patients may experience excessive skull bone growth, which can narrow the cranial foramina, an opening on the skull base through which many cranial nerves pass; this process can result in proptosis, blindness, deafness, and hydrocephalus. When bone tissue begins to replace bone marrow in the medullary cavity, it can cause severe bone marrow failure, resulting in pancytopenia. The body tries to compensate for bone marrow failure by stimulating extramedullary hematopoiesis in the liver and spleen, resulting in hepatosplenomegaly.  

Autosomal-dominant osteopetrosis type II presents with milder symptoms that manifest in early adulthood. Many patients are asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients may present with pathological fractures and early-onset osteoarthritis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Elevated serum calcium levels:
Incorrect: This patient has osteopetrosis, which is characterized by reduced osteoclast function. As a result, calcium is sequestered for bone mineralization but has difficulty being released via bone breakdown. As a result, patients with osteopetrosis present with reduced (or normal) calcium levels, depending on the condition’s severity.
✅ Reduced red blood cell count:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid:
Incorrect: Oligoclonal bands may be found in the cerebrospinal fluid of patients with multiple sclerosis. The condition can present with focal neurological deficits. However, it would be atypical for multiple sclerosis to cause pathological long-bone fractures or present in a patient this young.
❌ Increased parathyroid hormone production:
Incorrect: Hyperparathyroidism can cause increased bone resorption and predispose patients to fracture. However, hyperparathyroidism does not present with cranial nerve deficits. 
❌ Elevated alkaline phosphatase levels:
Incorrect: Conditions such as osteitis deformans, hyperparathyroidism, osteomalacia can present with this laboratory finding. However, the presence of pathological fractures and cranial nerve deficits in a young patient raise concerns for osteopetrosis, which does not typically cause elevated alkaline phosphatase levels.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the office because of non-radiating lower back pain. The pain has been present for the past 5 months and has progressively worsened. He has tried ibuprofen, which was initially able to control the pain but is no longer able to do so. He has no history of back trauma and does not perform any heavy lifting. Physical examination is notable for a decrease in height of 3 inches when compared with measurements taken one year ago and tenderness over the lumbar spine. Examination also reveals a slightly abnormal spine curvature. Radiographic studies are ordered, revealing anterior vertebral wedging and vertebral end-plate irregularity. What is the most likely underlying pathology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Decreased osteoblast activity, normal osteoclast activity
Increased osteoblast activity, decreased osteoclast activity
Decreased osteoblast activity, increased osteoclast activity

questions.solution:
This patient’s age, progressive back pain, height loss, and tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine raise concerns for a non-traumatic compression fracture. This diagnosis is confirmed by radiographic findings. In this patient, the condition is most likely due to osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is defined clinically as bone density that is less than 2.5 standard deviations below peak bone mass.

Osteoporosis can be divided into type I and type II. Type I osteoporosis affects postmenopausal females who have reduced estrogen production. Estrogen normally inhibits osteoclast resorption of bone; therefore, decreased estrogen levels leave the patient vulnerable to increased osteoclast breakdown of bone. Although osteoblast activity does increase to compensate, it ultimately cannot keep up with the resorptive process. For this reason, type I osteoporosis is also termed ‘high-turnover’ and ‘postmenopausal’ osteoporosis.

Type II osteoporosis affects both men and women. With age, osteoblasts lose their ability to proliferate and form new bone. Thus, after reaching a peak bone mass around age 30, decreased osteoblast activity will result in an overall decrease in bone density. This condition is also termed ‘low-turnover’ osteoporosis, since osteoclast activity is normal, and ‘senile’ osteoporosis, since it occurs universally with age in both genders. It is the most likely etiology of osteoporosis in this elderly male patient.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased osteoblast activity, normal osteoclast activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased osteoblast activity, decreased osteoclast activity:
Incorrect: Increased osteoblast activity with decreased osteoclast activity will result in an overall increase in bone mineral density, as seen in osteopetrosis. In contrast, this patient has a vertebral compression fracture, which is often due to bone weakness secondary to low mineral density.
❌ Intervertebral disc degeneration:
Incorrect: Intervertebral disc degeneration leads to disc herniation. Disc herniation can cause lower back pain secondary to nerve root compression, classically radiating to the lower extremities. This set of symptoms is termed sciatica. In contrast, this patient’s back pain is non-radiating, and the radiographic findings make a spinal compression fracture more likely.
❌ Intervertebral disc space calcification:
Incorrect: Intervertebral disc space calcification is a cause of pediatric spinal pain. The condition most often affects preadolescent children and self-resolves within 6 months.
❌ Decreased osteoblast activity, increased osteoclast activity:
Incorrect: Decreased osteoblast activity with increased osteoclast activity causes an overall decrease in bone density. It may lead to a vertebral compression fracture. However, this process occurs in type I 'postmenopausal’ osteoporosis, which is six times more common in women. In contrast, this man is more likely to have type II ‘senile’ osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to his primary care physician seeking evaluation for worsening pelvic pain. The pain is dull and constant, is present throughout the day, and is sometimes worse with weight-bearing. In addition, the patient complains of progressive hearing loss in both ears. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for warmth over the lateral pelvic walls and reduced sensorineural hearing loss in both ears. The remainder of the physical examination is noncontributory. A plain film radiograph of the pelvis is ordered and reveals significant sclerosis, with evidence of osteolytic lesions and cortical thickening. Which of the following set of serum laboratory findings will be most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has Paget disease of the bone (also termed osteitis deformans), a disorder characterized by abnormal bone remodeling. The condition most often involves the skull, lumbar vertebrae, pelvis, and femur.  

 The disease has four phases: 
  1.  Phase 1 is the lytic phase, wherein osteoclasts start to aggressively demineralize the bone up to 20 times more than normal.  
  2.  Phase 2 is the mixed phase, wherein there is rapid breakdown of existing bone and rapid deposition of new bone.  
  3.  Phase 3 is the sclerotic phase, which is when new bone formation exceeds bone resorption.  
  4.  Phase 4 is the quiescent phase, wherein both osteoblast and osteoclast activity is reduced. The net result is production of disorganized bone that is weaker than normal bone.  
Patients present with bone pain due to microfractures, erythema/warmth over affected areas, and increased shoe/hat size after puberty. In addition, changes in the shape of the skull can cause facial changes and cranial nerve impingement, which can present with sensorineural hearing loss. Laboratory findings, which reflect increased bone turnover, include elevated levels of serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP). In contrast, serum calcium and phosphorus are normal in most patients.  
 


Option Analysis

❌   Calcium  Phosphate Alkaline Phosphatase  ↓  Normal  Normal :
Incorrect: These findings can be seen in patients with osteopetrosis. The condition manifests during infancy or young adulthood. In patients with osteopetrosis, radiographic imaging will reveal diffuse bone sclerosis without osteolytic lesions.
✅   Calcium  Phosphate Alkaline Phosphatase  Normal Normal  ↑:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Calcium  Phosphate  Alkaline Phosphatase ↑↓ ↑ :
Incorrect: Hyperparathyroidism will cause elevated serum calcium and reduced serum phosphate levels. Bone turnover due to high parathyroid hormone levels will result in an elevated alkaline phosphatase. Although hyperparathyroidism can cause bony pain, the condition presents with cortical thinning on radiographic imaging. In contrast, this patient has cortical thickening.
❌   Calcium  Phosphate  Alkaline Phosphatase  ↓  ↓  ↑ :
Incorrect: Osteomalacia will present with these findings. In these patients, osteoblasts will deposit significant quantities of osteoid seam, explaining the elevated alkaline phosphatase level. However, not enough calcium or phosphate is available for the osteoid to mineralize and form mature bone. 
❌   Calcium  Phosphate Alkaline Phosphatase Normal  Normal  Normal :
Incorrect: These findings are seen in patients with osteoporosis. Osteoporosis can cause pathological fractures, which may present with skeletal pain. However, it would be atypical for osteoporosis to cause bilateral hearing loss.
